title: 114_hr699
content: The "Email Privacy Act" is the short title of this Act. It also includes provisions for voluntary disclosure corrections. Section 2702 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to change language regarding disclosure of electronic storage by service providers. Section 2702 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to specify the disclosure of electronic storage by service providers. This includes defining who can access communications stored by the provider with lawful consent. Section 2702 of title 18, United States Code is amended to specify the disclosure of electronic storage by service providers, allowing access to communications with lawful consent. AMENDMENTS TO REQUIRED DISCLOSURE SECTION. Section 2703 of title 18, United States Code is amended to require a governmental entity to obtain a warrant issued by a court of competent jurisdiction in order to disclose the contents of wire or electronic communications in electronic storage with a provider of electronic communication service. If the warrant does not specify a date for disclosure, the provider must promptly respond to the warrant. A governmental entity may require a provider of remote computing service to disclose the contents of stored electronic communications only with a warrant issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. If the warrant does not specify a disclosure date, the provider must promptly respond to it. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act allows governmental entities to request disclosure of records or information from providers of electronic communication or remote computing services, with certain exceptions. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act allows governmental entities to request disclosure of subscriber or customer information from providers of electronic communication or remote computing services under specific conditions, such as obtaining a warrant, court order, lawful consent, or other authorized means. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act allows providers of electronic communication or remote computing services to disclose subscriber or customer information to governmental entities under specific conditions, including name, address, telephone records, service details, and payment information, without requiring notice to the subscriber or customer. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act allows providers to disclose information to governmental entities without notifying the subscriber. The act also specifies the types of legal processes that can be used by governmental entities to obtain information. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act allows for the disclosure of wire or electronic communications by court-issued subpoenas or warrants to individuals or entities, including electronic communication service providers, for the purpose of disclosing stored communications to governmental entities. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act allows disclosure of wire or electronic communications that advertise products or services to the general public by remote computing or electronic communication service providers. This does not limit Congress's power to compel production of such communications. SEC. 4. DELAYED NOTICE. Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow a governmental entity to request a court order for delayed notification to a provider of electronic communication service. The court can grant up to 180 days of delayed notification if there are reasons to believe that immediate notification may endanger individuals, lead to flight from prosecution, evidence tampering, witness intimidation, jeopardize an investigation, or unduly delay a trial. Upon request by a governmental entity, a court may grant extensions of up to 180 days each for an order granted for delayed notification to a provider of electronic communication service. SEC. 5. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent the U.S. Government from acquiring wire or electronic communication contents under existing lawful authorities like the Wiretap Act or the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. It also allows the acquisition of subscriber information under the same laws. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
